Posts.Content: On 7/16/2008 Pat52 wrote: I was diagnosed with DCIS, stage 1 breast cancer in April of 2006. I had 2 lumpectomies in May and 30 radiation treatments that summer.  From 9/06-6/06, I took arimidex, as recommended by my oncologist.  Weight gain, fatigue, and especially nausea with vomiting were my symptoms during that whole period.  I took myself off of it, but my oncologist convinced me to try aromasin beginning in Dec. of 07.  I have been taking it for 7 months now, and I've never felt so bad daily for so long before.  My first trigger finger developed while on the aromosin.  I have had 2 cortisone shots to help temporarily and only slightly relieve that one.  I have same digit, middle finger, on right hand now, with very limited movement and lots of pain. The pain and stiffness in both hands and feet, is probably the most debilatating symptom for me.  I have trouble walking and using my hands normally.  I too, am so stiff after sitting for even a few minutes or when getting up in the morning, I feel like someone might feel at 100 years old.  My arms and legs hurt, as do my rib area and hips at times.  I go back to my oncologist for a regular check-up in a week, but I am quitting the aromasin TODAY!  My mammogram recently came back clear.  I don't know about the bloodwork yet, until my appt.  My fingers are so swollen.  I am CONSTANTLY tired, regardless of how much sleep I get, which has been about 8-9 hours a night this summer, since I am a teacher.  I rarely have any energy to do anything, but force my self too.  But I also find myself on the couch much of the time, if I really don't HAVE to do anything.  I hate being and feeling like this.  I will post another message in a few weeks to reflect on what I notice about being off the meds.  I'm 52, going on 92!   You poor, poor thing!  A year ago I was writing almost daily on this web with the same symptons.  It took a long time and I was going to give up on the Aromasin after changing from Arimidex.  However, whilst I still have3 the weight gain, sausage fingers, spread feet and a general "laziness", I have to say I feel great and can walk.  No pain any more.  It is hard for me to believe that I am the same person.  Wait and see what the oncologist says and then evaluate your quality of life, which, in the final analysis is what it is all about.  Good luck to you. Deliia Margaret

Posts.Content: On 6/1/2007 Kbcns7 wrote:   On 6/1/2007 Delia Margaret wrote: Advice needed.  Since taking Arimadex and then changing to Aromasin six months ago< I have developed HUGE swollen feet.  Two sizes larger and wider than normal. Resulting in my having to wear man's shoes or have shoes made.  My hands are like packets of sausages and I cannot wear any rings. This is causing me a degree of stress as I feel very ugly.  Is there anybody who has the answer for this?  I am going to a wedding abroad next month and am heartbroken at the thought of wearing sneakers!!!!! Please can anybody tell me what to do? Delia I took Arimidex for four years and had huge negative consequences and became very "mannish", but never had unusual swelling. Is Arimidex the only drug you're taking? Did you tell your doctor that you have this problem? You might ask your doctor if you can suspend treatment for a week or two to see what happen s. A week or two off of a treatment never really hurt anybody. Do you really need estrogen suppression? I wish you the best but always complain and  complain andcomplain about side effects to your doctor and don't leave the office without answers.   Thank you for your reply suggesting a "time out" from the Arimidex or Aromasin but I have tried this without success.  There just has to be a way of getting rid of those swollen feet and hands.  I am glad you escaped.  Good luck for the future. Delia

Posts.Title: Arimidex and Zometa

Posts.Content: Since I completed my breast surgery,  and forty six lymph nodes removed,Chemotherapy and Radiation,three years ago, I have had Eight attacks of Cellulitis, a serious bacterial infecion of the lower layer of the skin, which is attached to the connective tissue.  It results i.  n a high fever and purpley red breasts, ribcage and back, where there is scar tissue. I have been hospitalized for a minimum of two weeks  and maximum of four weeks on round the clock IV. The doctors both in Europe and in New York, tell me that this is caused by the radiation, although the first attack began just after I started Chemotherapy and before I started Radio therapy.  They tell me that I shall have to live like this  for the rest of my life.  I had four attacks last year alone and my body is loaded with anti-biotics. My general health is good ,but I would love to have some answers on how I could help myself prevent this. Thank you. Delia Does anyone have any ideas?
Posts.Title: Radiation and reoccurring Cellulitis

Posts.Content: On 9/10/2008 courtney1 wrote: I had a lumpectomy last Jan. and just finished chemo, radiation etc. I visited with a plastic surgeon today about reconstruction. I had infection and have a indentation in the side of my left breast along with the nipple pulled to the side. Has anyone ever had flap surgery (from the back muscle), and what were your results. How did the recovery go? Is there a wait period after radiation? Also I am having pain under my arm and along the bra line under the breat, has anyone ever had that before? Thanks in advance for you help.   'Dear Courtney, I had the flap operation you refer to a year and a half ago.  Like you I had had an infection that wouldn't heal.  It was a piece of cake and I wish I had done it sooner but I was apprehensive of further infections.  Hardly a scar and not soreness or pain.  Now the other pain you refer to I get occasionaly and was told the other day that it is from the radium.  The muscle pulls away from the breast bone and can hurt.  I suppose we just get used to those bi-products of the whole silly business.  But the flap is a breeze.  Gook luck!!  Delia

Posts.Title: Body pains

Posts.Content: This might be of interest.  I have had fourteen atttacks of recurring cellulitis over the past three years.  Finally it has been suggested that the reason is radiation burn, combined with mild soriasis ,allowing entry of the ¨bugs¨.  I have just completed ten sessions of HYPERBARIC THERAPY and see a complete regeneration of the breast tissue.  I am also taking a profilactic antibiotic called CALVEPEN 666mg once a day for the forseeable future.   But the best part of all is that, due to the hyperbaric treatments, my hair has grown thick and after three years of wispy, thin strands, it looks like normal hair.  YIPPEEEEEEEE!!!!!!!!The nails grown strong and long too.  But it was the hair loss that made me so miserable.  I hope this is of some help. Delia
Posts.Title: Recurring Cellulitis

Posts.Content: I was operated on four years ago today for breast cancer.  After serious infections, chemo and radiation and a "flap" operation to close up open the wound after 18 months of daily dressing, I seemed on the road to recovery. Yes ,Hair never did return to former luxurient growth (dammit!) and for many months there was a very painful adjustment to the Arimidex, which disappeared on changing to Aromasin.  My feet and hands are chubby and two sizes larger, but what the heck!  Aren't I alive?  Now my question is?  Does anyone know how I can avoid the recurring cellulitis I have endured since the beginning?  I have had nine different episodes each involving being on a drip in hospital for either two weeks or four weeks at a time.  In the past 12 months I have been in hospital for four and a half MONTHS pumping those dreaded anti biotics into me.  My doctors look pityingly at me and say " you are just unlucky".  I have decided NOT GOOD ENOUGH!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!  I get it on my breasts, ribcage and back especially where there is scar tissue. There seems to be excessive radiation burn ,although I did not have any adverese effects at the time.  I can NOT plan anything in my life and would so appreciate any input, if any, from out there.   Kindest regards, Delia
